Tom Emerson wrote:

> How should I go about figuring out what I'm doing wrong. The order of 
> decide rules is:
> 
> rejectByDefault
> acceptIfSurtPrefixed
> rejectIfTooManyHops
> acceptIfTranscluded
> rejectIfPathological
> rejectIfTooManyPathSegs
> acceptHtmlOnly <--- MatchesRegExpDecideRule with regexp .*(?i)\.html?
> acceptIfPrerequisite
> 
> Not only do I seem to be getting non-HTML files (which I thought would 
> be filtered with the regexp decide rule) but I'm getting stuff outside 
> my SURTs.
> 
> Should the acceptIfSurtPrefixed be moved below the others? Perhaps 
> acceptIfTranscluded is overriding the setting?

These rules are tested in order -- if you really want to be certain you 
don't go beyond the SURT scope at all, don't have any other ACCEPT rules 
after the acceptIfSurtPrefixed (except the acceptIfPrerequisite -- which 
makes sure that the crawler will be able to get DNS and robots.txt 
prereqs.)  Specifically, acceptIfTranscluded is probably allowing a 
number of off-site images/redirects/etc to be fetched, even though they 
are outside of the exact SURT scope.

Also, if you want HTML _ONLY_, you probably want to change that rule to 
a rule that REJECTs if NotMatchesRegExpDecideRule with regexp 
.*(?i)\.html?   The rule you have will merely accept anything matching 
that, it won't change the ACCEPT/REJECT result for things that do not match.

So, I think you might be looking for something like:
rejectByDefault
acceptIfSurtPrefixed
rejectIfTooManyHops
rejectIfPathological
rejectIfTooManyPathSegs
rejectNonHTML <--- NotMatchesRegExpDecideRule with regexp .*(?i)\.html?
acceptIfPrerequisite


Mike
